intro: Rubus ulmifolius var. tenacellus, commonly known as the creeping blackberry, is a variant of the common blackberry that exhibits a more sprawling growth habit. It is characterized by its thorny stems and compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, dark purple to black berries that are typically edible. It thrives in a variety of soil types and is often found in hedgerows and woodland edges. Its botanical features make it a hardy and adaptable species within the Rubus genus.
